awd_titl_txt: Methods and Applications for Massive One-mode and Bipartite Social Networks
awd_abstract_narration:
This research project will advance methods of estimation and inference for large-scale network models. The modeling of network data has important applications in many areas, including sociology, economics, marketing, and public health. The project will extend methods from the one-mode network setting (such as social media networks) to the bipartite network setting (such as worker-employer networks). Using data from the U.S. Census Bureau and the newly developed methods, the project will examine the impact of immigration on the U.S. job market over time. Theoretical and empirical analyses will be complemented by the development and dissemination of open source software that implements the new methods and enables analyses of large-scale social and economic networks. The project's interdisciplinary team of researchers will train and mentor graduate students in the social sciences and statistics.

This research project will develop new modeling capabilities and statistical inference for latent space network models, specifically generalized random dot product graphs. An overarching goal of the project will be to disentangle the effect of observable and unobservable node characteristics on the process of link formation in a manner that is both statistically principled and computationally feasible. Project results will include methods for both one-mode networks and bipartite networks, as well as for both static and dynamic networks. Asymptotic spectral theory and computationally efficient procedures for understanding bipartite networks will be developed. Spectral estimates for bipartite networks will be used to correct for network endogeneity in regression models. Combining spectral approaches with classical regression procedures from network econometrics will facilitate the development of effective alternatives to existing methods in the analysis of how networks impact socioeconomic outcomes. Using these new methods, the project will examine the impact of immigration on the U.S. job market with data from the Longitudinal Employer-Household Dynamics program.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Social, Behavioral and Economic Sciences
org_div_long_name: Division of Social and Economic Sciences

por.por_cntn:
Networks are ubiquitous in social science, physics, neuroscience, business, and many other disciplines. The study of social, physical, biological and economic networks provides important information about the patterns of interactions and conflict arising in complex systems. In many networks, there are attributes of the nodes that are observable to the researcher while other characteristics are unobservable. For example, in a social network, we may have information on gender, race, marital status, etc. for each individual in the system, while we may not be able to observe their personality, motivation, mood. Both observable and unobservable attributes affect individual’s willingness to interact and form relationships, so it is important to develop a framework to study both factors affecting the shape of the network. 

 

In this project we aimed to study large network datasets, and we developed methods that are computationally fast and have good statistical properties. In particular, our methods allow a researcher to study the effect of observable and unobservable characteristics that affect the network. Our method is based on a model of network formation where links are independently formed, but still have some dependency structure based on underlying unobservable variables. We started from this model, the Random Dot Product Graph, and incorporated the effect of observable characteristics on the probability of links between two nodes. We then developed Adjacency Spectral Embeddings (ASE) to disentangle the effect of observable and unobservable nodal characteristics on the structure of the network. Our method exploits the fact that the structure of the network is usually encoded in the spectral properties of the adjacency matrix that describes the patterns of interactions among nodes. Our ASE is computationally faster than several alternative estimators and guarantees good statistical properties in large network datasets. 

 

We initially applied our methods to single networks observed at a specific point in time, to learn the community structure of the system of interactions. More recently, the team has extended the methodology to study multiple (independent and dependent) networks and networks observed over time. Some of the methodology is also an important building block for estimation of more complex models, such as exponential random graphs with community structure. 

 


Last Modified: 10/28/2024
Modified by: Angelo Mele
